8.text:
8 (a)  
Answer: 8  
Marks: 3 (2 AO1.3a, 1 AO3.1b)  
• M1 for dividing by 3 or 13  
• M1 for dividing by remaining factor  
• M1 for multiplying 3 by 13  
• M1 for dividing by 39 or listing multiples of 39  

(b)  
Answer: Any three valid answers (e.g. 2, 7, 23)  
Marks: 3 (1 AO1.1, 2 AO3.1a)  
• B1 for each  
• If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for at least 3 primes and 3 squares seen

9.text:
9 (a)  
Answer: 2  
Marks: 2  
• B1 for 2 correct  

Prism               | Number of faces | Number of edges | Number of vertices |  
--------------------|-----------------|-----------------|--------------------  
Triangular (3 sides)  | 5               | 9               | 6                  (1 AO1.1)  
Rectangular (4 sides) | 6               | 12              | 8                  (1 AO2.1a)  
Pentagonal (5 sides)  | 7               | 15              | 10  
Hexagonal (6 sides)   | 8               | 18              | 12  

9 (b)  
Answer: 300 (edges), 200 (vertices)  
Marks: 1 + 1 (2 AO2.1a)  

9 (c)  
Answer: F = N + 2 oe  
Marks: 2 (1 AO2.3a, 1 AO2.3b)  
• B1 for N + 2 (without a subject)  
• Condone for B1 a correct word formula

10.text:
10 (a)  
 (i)  Answer: Positive correlation  
      Marks: 1  
      AO: 1 AO1.1  
      Guidance:  
         • Condone “positive” or correct description  
           (e.g. “As the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold.”)  

 (ii) Answer: Correct reason, e.g.  
       “He sold far more ice creams than you would expect him to for a 20 °C day.”  
      Marks: 1  
      AO: 1 AO2.3a  

(b)  
 (i)   Answer: 75 – 95  
       Marks: 1  
       AO: 1 AO1.3a  

 (ii)  Answer: 140 – 170  
       Marks: 1  
       AO: 1 AO1.3a  

 (iii) Answer: The (b)(i) prediction is more reliable, as it is within the range of the given data  
       Marks: 2  
       AO: 1 AO2.1b, 1 AO2.4a  
       Guidance:  
         • B1 for (b)(i) prediction identified with partial reason  

(c)  
 Answer: No, because there may be other factors involved  
 Marks: 2  
 AO: 1 AO2.5a, 1 AO3.4b  
 Guidance:  
   • B1 for “No” with partial reason

11.text:
11 (a) 45 000  
 2 marks  
 2 AO1.3a  
 M1 for 50 000 × 0.9 soi  
  or 50 000 − 5000  

(b) Total value of goods sold in May was £32 805, which is less than £35 000  
 3 marks  
 3 AO2.2  
 M2 for 50 000 (or 45 000) × 0.9 used three times (or two times) soi or decreasing by 10% three times  
 Or  
 M1 for 45 000 × 0.9 or 45 000 − 4500  
  Implied by 36 450 and 32 805  
  Implied by 40 500  

(c) 8[%] with correct working  
 5 marks  
 3 AO1.3b  
 2 AO3.1d  
 B4 for answer 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with correct working  

 or  

 M3 for 1.2 × [0].9 oe  
    or for  
    (100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 − 100 000) / 100 000  

 or  

 M2 for 1.2 and [0].9  

 or  

 M1 for 1.2 or [0].9  

 If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 8[%] with no working or insufficient working  

 If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with no working or insufficient working  

 “Correct working” requires evidence of at least M3 or alternative convincing approach  

 Throughout, percentage calculations may be performed in stages, e.g. 120% by adding 20%  
 e.g. 100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 or 120 000 × [0].9  
 e.g. 100 000 × 1.2 implied by 120 000

12 (b)  
Answer: –3, –5

• M2 for (x + 3)(x + 5) seen or implied in table

15.text:
15 (a)  
Answer: 800  
Marks: 2 (1 AO1.3b, 1 AO3.1c)  
• M1 for unitary work, for example “1 person does 200 letters in 2 hours.”

15 (b)  
Answer: 30 minutes (oe)  
Marks: 4 (2 AO2.1a, 2 AO3.1d)  
• M1 for “1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour.”  
• M1 for “5 people do 1000 letters in 2 hours.”  
• M1 for “4 people do 1000 letters in 2.5 hours.”  
• FT from their rate in (a) throughout.

15 (c)  
Marks: 2 (1 AO3.4a, 1 AO3.5)  
• B1 for a correct comment on the assumption’s reasonableness, e.g.  
  “She has assumed that ‘all day’ means ‘for 24 hours’, but it is not reasonable for them to work without a break.”  
• B1 for a correct comment on the effect it has on the answer, e.g.  
  “They can’t work at that rate for that long, so her answer is an over-estimate.”

18.text:
18 (a)  
The first error is in step 2  
–3x – 2x = –5x, not –x as given  
2 marks (2 AO2.5a)  
• B1 for identifying step 2  
• B1 for explaining the error  

(b)  
[x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² – 3x – 2x + 6]  
x² + 5x + 4 = x² – 5x + 6  
5x + 4 = –5x + 6  
10x + 4 = 6  
10x = 2  
x = 1/5  

2 marks (2 AO1.3a)  
• M1 for an attempt to correct the solution in line with their answer to (a)
